History : 
 Cathrineholm of Norway is responsible for the simple and attractive enamelware that was a staple in households across Scandinavia and America in the 50s, 60s, and 70s. Their iconic lotus pattern is their most recognizable, and a classic of mid-century modern design. The designer responsible for this striking collection was a woman by the name of Grete Prytz Kittelsen. Kittelsen, often referred to as the “Queen of Scandinavian Design,” was known for her beautiful work with sterling, enamel, and other metals. Her designs earned her numerous awards, as well as well-deserved attention as an inspiration and integral part of the Scandinavian Design movement.

Check out this blog on the subject : 
https://ampersandvintagemodern.wordpress.com/tag/cathrineholm/

FUN FACTS :
Fostoria Glassworks began in 1887 in Fostoria, Ohio, and later relocated to Moundsville, West Virginia. Surviving the Great Depression, Fostoria remained a leader in the glassware market with its line of colored stemware and luxury dinnerware. In 1983, Fostoria closed its doors, but the Fostoria brand remains highly collectible as a legendary American icon.

Grapette was developed by Benjamin "Tyndle" Fooks when, while working as a traveling salesman selling a product known as "Fooks Flavors", he noticed the popularity of his grape flavor. From this, Fooks, dissatisfied with existing grape sodas on the market, sought to develop a grape soda that tasted the way he believed that a grape soda should taste. Over the course of two years and tens of thousands of taste tests, by 1939, he had developed a flavor that he believed was superior to all other grape sodas available at the time. - Wikipedia

Only very light surface scratching noted on pieces ( some have none) - they appear to have had little use and have been well taken care of!  
Gorgeous Hand Painted Earthenware with a raised pink rose pattern!

NOTE: 
Please specify if you would specifically like the Brown Logo plates  - I will try to accommodate you as availability allows.  If no specific logo is requested, I will choose the plates that are similar in coloring and manufacture period for you. 

FUN FACT:
Desert Rose, by Franciscan Dinnerware  is one of the largest-selling casual tableware patterns in the history of dinnerware. Mary Jane Winans, a Franciscan artist, designed and sculpted the Desert Rose pattern. The light pinks and greens of this pattern’s earthenware body perfectly accent the scalloped vine and rose border.  The Desert Rose pattern was introduced in 1941, and during the ensuing decades over 100 different piece types were produced. Franciscan Desert Rose was produced in the US from 1941-1984, in England from 1985-2003, and in China and Thailand since 2004. There is a variance in color between these time periods.

STETSON China Co
Lincoln Illinois 
Handpainted Underglaze 

Great pieces to use for display or add to an existing collection !

FUN FACT : 
Louis B. Stetson, opened the Stetson China Company in 1919 in Chicago. Louis' nephew Joseph W. Stetson joined the firm during its first year. Joe was 21 years old when he joined Stetson China. In February 1946, the Stetson China Company purchased the Illinois China Company located in Lincoln, Illinois. Stetson China moved its main base of operations to Lincoln in 1946, but it had been in business for 27 years before that, mainly based in Chicago. Lincoln plant produced pottery from 1946- 1966. 

Individual items were painted systematically.  Instructors trained women in painting a particular image.  Then, each painter "sat at a table, picking up a plate from a moving belt, painting her part, then putting it back on the belt.  She was paid a salary and also by the piece" .  Some women would paint individual leaves or clusters of them; some might paint just dots; and more advanced painters did whole flowers.

SOLD 19" platter - marking dates  1949 - 53  - MADE IN CALIFORNIA  with individual number ( unable to read)
SOLD- 14" platter - marking dated  1948 - 49   - Hand Decorated Franciscan Made in California with individual  number 
12"  platter - marking dated 1949 - 53  - MADE IN CALIFORNIA  with individual number ( unable to read)

Gorgeous Hand Painted Earthenware with a raised floral pattern!

Desert Rose, by Franciscan Dinnerware  is one of the largest-selling casual tableware patterns in the history of dinnerware. Mary Jane Winans, a Franciscan artist, designed and sculpted the Desert Rose pattern. The light pinks and greens of this pattern’s earthenware body perfectly accent the scalloped vine and rose border.  The Desert Rose pattern was introduced in 1941, and during the ensuing decades over 100 different piece types were produced. Franciscan Desert Rose was produced in the US from 1941-1984, in England from 1985-2003, and in China and Thailand since 2004. There is a variance in color between these time periods.

TITLE: Vintage Chic clutch purse, Mid century Elegance Evans Black satin evening bag w/ coin purse and mirror, vintage evening bag /clutch Art Deco
DESCRIPTION:
CLASSY! 

VERY GOOD vintage condition!!!!! 

This wonderful vintage  clutch purse in black satin-like finish is an original EVANS evening purse. This beauty was designed and manufactured by Evans Case Company in the early 1950’s. Made by master artisans in Attleborough, Massachusetts, United States the quality of materials and precision of workmanship is flawless. 

In addition to this quality handbag, are its original matching accessories: change purse with gold tone chain and mirror 

The extremely well made, timeless style handbag carries the raised metal Elegance Evans  logo on the inside of the bag. The outside of the clutch  is adorned with an exquisite round jeweled clasp.  The clasp closes securely - NOTE : it is missing one jeweled stone on the right side ( note photo close up) 

The interior of the designer case is lined with off white/pale yellow  satin. There are three kangaroo pockets. The interior of the purse is clean and without signs of wear, but there is a slight makeup stain on the crease of the inside . The coin purse is attached to the inside of the clutch with a delicate gold chain and a small hand help mirror fits nicely into one of the many pockets.  

The outer satin on this  accessory is in very good condition. There is no staining, tears or odors noted. 

Clutch measures approximately 10" X 6" 

Both the style and quality of Evans products made them popular with the 1940’s and 1950’s rich and famous, including a long list of movie stars who graced their advertising efforts. This beautiful Evans design is a vintage gem.

Here's a tidbit about this pottery : 
Frankoma Pottery was founded by John Frank in Norman, Oklahoma 1933. John Frank had been a professor in ceramics at the University of Oklahoma at Norman from 1927 to 1936 and used light-hued local Ada clay in his initial products. He moved the company to Sapulpa in 1938, only to soon rebuild that factory after a fire later that year.[3] The name Frankoma was created from Frank's last name and the last three letters of the state of Oklahoma.

FUN FACT : 
Louis B. Stetson, opened the Stetson China Company in 1919 in Chicago. Louis' nephew Joseph W. Stetson joined the firm during its first year. Joe was 21 years old when he joined Stetson China. In February 1946, the Stetson China Company purchased the Illinois China Company located in Lincoln, Illinois. Stetson China moved its main base of operations to Lincoln in 1946, but it had been in business for 27 years before that, mainly based in Chicago.

FUN FACT : 
Louis B. Stetson, opened the Stetson China Company in 1919 in Chicago. Louis' nephew Joseph W. Stetson joined the firm during its first year. Joe was 21 years old when he joined Stetson China. In February 1946, the Stetson China Company purchased the Illinois China Company located in Lincoln, Illinois. Stetson China moved its main base of operations to Lincoln in 1946, but it had been in business for 27 years before that, mainly based in Chicago. Lincoln plant produced pottery from 1946- 1966. 

Individual items were painted systematically.  Instructors trained women in painting a particular image.  Then, each painter "sat at a table, picking up a plate from a moving belt, painting her part, then putting it back on the belt.  She was paid a salary and also by the piece" .  Some women would paint individual leaves or clusters of them; some might paint just dots; and more advanced painters did whole flowers.

TITLE: 4 Vintage Pressed Glass Water Goblets, Mid Century pedestal goblets Hazel Atlas Gothic ice tea/ water glasses, wedding table, 1950's glasses
DESCRIPTION:
FOUR (4)  Vintage Hazel Atlas Glass Co Pressed Glass Gothic Footed Glass Tumblers ~ great for mismatch wedding table place settings! 

7 sets of FOUR available

This is a GREAT set of vintage  glass goblets from the 1950s ~  manufactured by Hazel Atlas in the Gothic pattern.   Each pressed glass is decorated with a diamond and fan motif on the sides of the goblet and stem. Bottoms have a starburst motif.

This glassware was used by Big Top as a promotional item to package  their peanut butter. Glasses were  sold with a metal lid and filled with peanut butter .  Mid century housewives  were eager to buy the peanut butter to collect glasses for their tables.  Hazel Atlas also sold the glasses, cups, saucers, and plates separately under the name of Gothic glassware. 

Measurements - approximately 5 3/4" tall with a 3" diameter and footed base 
Holds approximately 10 ounces 

All goblets are in VERY GOOD vintage condition with no chips or cracks noted. 
Rims are smooth to the touch. Most glasses have little to no clouding/ scaling on the inside of the glass - this is noted when the glasses are held up to light. Blog : 
http://southernvintagetable.wordpress.com/2014/02/02/vintage-feature-the-magic-behind-vintage-blue-ridge-china/


Taken from the blog above : 
The history behind this unique style of dishware is a great American story about a once thriving pottery in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Tennessee.  Although our current inventory of Blue Ridge is limited, our appreciation at Southern Vintage Table for this American-made china is growing!
The story begins in the early 1900s when a railroad company sold a large parcel of land along their railroad line in Erwin, Tennessee to a group of investors. There were rich deposits of kaolinite and feldspar nearby, perfect ingredients for a pottery business. According to Wikipedia, in 1916 Clinchfield Potteries opened their doors for business, manufacturing the typical china style of the times which were described as “gold-trimmed, decal-decorated dishes”.
In the 1920s the business was sold and became known as Southern Potteries. To set his style of china apart from his competitors, the new owner introduced a hand painted, underglaze technique. The bold, new patterns, painted by the local women, were stamped with the new label, Blue Ridge, sometime during the 1930s.

Here's a tidbit about this pottery : 
Frankoma Pottery was founded by John Frank in Norman, Oklahoma 1933. John Frank had been a professor in ceramics at the University of Oklahoma at Norman from 1927 to 1936 and used light-hued local Ada clay in his initial products. He moved the company to Sapulpa in 1938, only to soon rebuild that factory after a fire later that year.[3] The name Frankoma was created from Frank's last name and the last three letters of the state of Oklahoma.

FUN FACT : 
Louis B. Stetson, opened the Stetson China Company in 1919 in Chicago. Louis' nephew Joseph W. Stetson joined the firm during its first year. Joe was 21 years old when he joined Stetson China. In February 1946, the Stetson China Company purchased the Illinois China Company located in Lincoln, Illinois. Stetson China moved its main base of operations to Lincoln in 1946, but it had been in business for 27 years before that, mainly based in Chicago.

FUN FACT : 
Louis B. Stetson, opened the Stetson China Company in 1919 in Chicago. Louis' nephew Joseph W. Stetson joined the firm during its first year. Joe was 21 years old when he joined Stetson China. In February 1946, the Stetson China Company purchased the Illinois China Company located in Lincoln, Illinois. Stetson China moved its main base of operations to Lincoln in 1946, but it had been in business for 27 years before that, mainly based in Chicago. Lincoln plant produced pottery from 1946- 1966. 

Individual items were painted systematically.  Instructors trained women in painting a particular image.  Then, each painter "sat at a table, picking up a plate from a moving belt, painting her part, then putting it back on the belt.  She was paid a salary and also by the piece" .  Some women would paint individual leaves or clusters of them; some might paint just dots; and more advanced painters did whole flowers.

FUN FACTS :

Fostoria Glassworks began in 1887 in Fostoria, Ohio, and later relocated to Moundsville, West Virginia. Surviving the Great Depression, Fostoria remained a leader in the glassware market with its line of colored stemware and luxury dinnerware. In 1983, Fostoria closed its doors, but the Fostoria brand remains highly collectible as a legendary American icon.

TITLE: Antique Neoclassical Three Face Covered Clear and Frosted Glass Candy Dish Compote LG Wright, collectible glass pedestal bowl with lid
DESCRIPTION:
Vintage clear and frosted glass Three Face covered compote candy dish is also known as Three Fates, Three Graces and Three Sisters. 

This design was introduced by John Ernest Miller, mold-shop superintendent for George Duncan and Sons in Pittsburgh, PA, and is rumored to be a likeness of his wife Elizabeth. The design was patented in June of 1878 and was originally called pattern No. 400. L. G. Wright Glass Company produced copies of the design in the late 1960’s. 

Ladies features, hair and jewelry are detailed and crisp. The stem and base of the piece are acid finished giving them a frosted appearance and a satiny feel. The lid and bowl are clear glass.

VERY GOOD vintage condition with no chips or cracking. Faces show no rough spots or nicking. 

The compote measures 6 1/4” in diameter and is 4 1/2” tall without the lid. With the lid in place, the piece measures approximately 8 1/2” tall. The diameter of the base is approximately 3 3/4”.

Pieces are marked : Blue Ridge Potteries / Southern Potteries 

Southern Potteries Blue Ridge Pottery plates SUNNY SPRAY vintage hand painted plates w/ floral design, mid century plates yellow brown green ~ These plates have the distinct look of Blue Ridge pottery ~ Beautiful hand painted designs featuring Yellow and Brown flowers 

They are also the perfect house warming gift for the new neighbors….add some homemade cookies and you will be the new favorite in the neighborhood!! 

Blog : 
http://southernvintagetable.wordpress.com/2014/02/02/vintage-feature-the-magic-behind-vintage-blue-ridge-china/


Taken from the blog above : 
The history behind this unique style of dishware is a great American story about a once thriving pottery in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Tennessee.  Although our current inventory of Blue Ridge is limited, our appreciation at Southern Vintage Table for this American-made china is growing!
The story begins in the early 1900s when a railroad company sold a large parcel of land along their railroad line in Erwin, Tennessee to a group of investors. There were rich deposits of kaolinite and feldspar nearby, perfect ingredients for a pottery business. According to Wikipedia, in 1916 Clinchfield Potteries opened their doors for business, manufacturing the typical china style of the times which were described as “gold-trimmed, decal-decorated dishes”.
In the 1920s the business was sold and became known as Southern Potteries. To set his style of china apart from his competitors, the new owner introduced a hand painted, underglaze technique. The bold, new patterns, painted by the local women, were stamped with the new label, Blue Ridge, sometime during the 1930s.

DESCRIPTION:
SOLD INDIVIDUALLY

PATTERN: Desert Rose - Dinner plate

All are in VERY GOOD Vintage condition- no chips, cracks or crazing in the glaze. Glaze is bright and plates have a shiny glaze. One plate has a tiny nick on the edge - this will be sold last. ( see photos) 

Pieces are marked with the brown TV logo lettering: 
Franciscan Earthenware 
Made in the USA 
Oven Safe Color Fast 
with individual numbers ( not able to read) 

Marking dates 1958 - 63 

Gorgeous Hand Painted Earthenware with a raised pink rose pattern!

Desert Rose, by Franciscan Dinnerware  is one of the largest-selling casual tableware patterns in the history of dinnerware. Mary Jane Winans, a Franciscan artist, designed and sculpted the Desert Rose pattern. The light pinks and greens of this pattern’s earthenware body perfectly accent the scalloped vine and rose border.  The Desert Rose pattern was introduced in 1941, and during the ensuing decades over 100 different piece types were produced. Franciscan Desert Rose was produced in the US from 1941-1984, in England from 1985-2003, and in China and Thailand since 2004. There is a variance in color between these time periods.

Check out my shop for other pieces in this pattern !

Fun Fact : 
Noritake Progression China was first produced in 1964 with marketing commencing in 1966 to the USA. Noritake’s Progression China was sold as 'Oven-to-table-to-dishwasher-to freezer' ware. Noritake Progression China was a heat-resistant reinforced tableware, suitable for use in both gas and electric ovens and then for serving on the table. Noritake Progression China when first sold had a 2-year warranty for free replacement for normal household use to customers in the USA only. Noritake Progression China was discontinued 1983.

A black leather band circles the base of the hat - also in excellent condition 


How to care for your Hat :

*Always handle your hat by the brim. (Do not pinch the crown to pick it up as this will result in misshapen crowns and may split the felt.)

*Never rest your hat on its brim. Always turn it upside down and set it on the crown, so that the brim doesn’t flatten out.

*Clean your hat regularly using a soft bristle brush or a hat sponge.

*Brush counter clockwise with the nap, starting at the bow. If you get caught in the rain, turn the sweatband out and let the hat stand on the crown until dry.

*Never apply direct heat to your hat as this will cause it to shrink and/or lose it’s shape.

* Always store your hat in a hat box to help keep it clean and looking new.

Fun Fact : 
Tiffin is a popular United States glass manufacturer with a history dating back to 1888 with A. J. Beatty & Sons and the U. S. Glass Company. The company was purchased by Interpace and produced a line of glassware (Madeira) to complement the Franciscan dinnerware patterns. The final end came to the company in 1980 when production ceased.
